subject: AI
title: Dead-Letter Queues
description: What to do with messages that fail repeatedly.

hook.text: An email can't be classified after 3 retries. Do you lose it? Ignore it? The dead-letter queue catches it â€” a holding area for messages that couldn't be processed.

buildup.text: A dead-letter queue (DLQ) stores messages that failed processing after all retries. Instead of losing the data, you park it for human review or later reprocessing.

discovery.text: Monitor the DLQ: if it grows, something systemic is wrong (model degradation, API changes, data format shifts). The DLQ is an early warning system for workflow health.

twist.text: DLQs can grow silently. A hundred failed messages per day don't trigger alerts if nobody set one up. Monitor DLQ size and age â€” old messages indicate forgotten failures.

climax.text: Every production workflow needs a DLQ: catch failures, monitor volume, alert on growth, and review regularly. No data should silently disappear.

punchline.text: If you can't process it, don't lose it. Dead-letter queues turn silent failures into visible ones.

quiz.question: What does a dead-letter queue indicate when it grows rapidly?
options: Something systemic is wrong â€” model degradation, API changes, or data format shifts
The workflow is running too fast
